data.title: Václav Havel, Dissident, Playwright, and Czech President
data.meta_description: Václav Havel was a unique figure in the modern history of the Czech Republic and former Czechoslovakia.
data.text:
Václav Havel was a unique figure in the modern history of the Czech Republic and former Czechoslovakia.

The story of a man who found the courage to stand up to the totalitarian regime of communist Czechoslovakia has many layers. From the absurdities of life in an unfree regime, to international respect and the dominoes falling to the creation of an almost cult of personality. During the political year of 1989, Václav Havel made his way from prison to Prague Castle and became a beacon to which most of the nation, unaccustomed to a life of freedom, quite logically gravitated towards.

Life of Vaclav Havel

Václav Havel was born on 5th October 1936 in Prague into a wealthy businessman’s family. His family belonged to the intellectual and cultural elite. What could have been happiness soon turned into a burden. After the communists came to power, an unsuitable (i.e., “bourgeois”) background became a major obstacle to obtaining an education. All his attempts to gain admission to a university in the humanities were unsuccessful. Eventually, he was admitted to the Czech Technical University, where he studied economics. He finally gained admission to the Academy of Performing Arts (AMU) in 1962 as a distance learner.

Prague Spring

Václav Havel’s public involvement also began in the 1960s. During the Prague Spring of 1968, he argued that more than just reform of the Communist Party and its style of government should be demanded. Instead of mere democratisation, he wanted democracy. However, all hopes were dashed by the Soviet invasion*. All those who had actively supported the revival process in the spring of 1968 became “enemies of the people” a year later, or more precisely the arch enemies of the new leadership. Havel faced his first interrogations and accusations of the crime of subversion of the republic.

Dissent and Charter77

Havel becomes the leading figure of the Czechoslovak dissident movement. He is one of the authors of the Charter 77 declaration, a document that exposed human rights violations in the then totalitarian society. The petition was signed in December 1976 by over 200 personalities in Czechoslovakia, including intellectuals, artists, writers, and other activists. This time he did not escape prison. He was sentenced in 1979 and was not released from prison until 1983. He was arrested and sentenced again in 1989, this time spending only a few months in prison. In the same year, a major turning point occured in the life of Václav Havel and the whole of Czechoslovak society. The Velvet Revolution sweeps away the communist regime and Václav Havel becomes the country’s president.

The Velvet Revolution

On 17 November 1989, the so-called Velvet Revolution began with the dispersal of a student demonstration, ending forty years of communist rule in Czechoslovakia. On 19th November, Václav Havel participated in the founding of the Civic Forum, an anti-totalitarian movement uniting reformist and democratic forces in the Czech part of the federation, and from the beginning he was one of its most influential representatives. Václav Havel played a key role during the Velvet Revolution in 1989. His courage and charisma contributed to the mobilisation of citizens and the fall of the communist regime.

President

Václav Havel supported the country’s move towards parliamentary democracy and the political structures of Western civilisation, but in 1992 he failed to prevent the collapse of the Czechoslovak state.

As president, Havel sought to create an open, democratic, and moral society. During his presidency, he emphasised the values of human rights, civil society, and democracy. Although he did not have a traditional political background, he gained respect both in the Czech Republic and abroad for his charisma, moral stance, and intellectual heritage.

Havel was known for his informal style and approach to politics. He refused to be a mere ceremonial president and often commented on current political issues. His presidential style was characterized by open dialogue and an effort to overcome political disagreements. Havel also played a key role in taking some important decisions, such as the adoption of the new constitution of the Czech Republic in 1992.

Václav Havel and the USA

Václav Havel delivered his legendary speech to the United States Congress on 21st February 1990, during his first visit to the United States after the fall of the communist regime in Czechoslovakia. This speech was a key moment in relations between the United States and the newly emerging democratic countries of Central and Eastern Europe.

Václav Havel maintained close relations with several American politicians. He was a friend of President Bill Clinton. He had good relations with other prominent figures, which contributed to the strengthening of diplomatic and cultural ties between the Czech Republic and the USA.

Leaving politics

After leaving politics, he devoted himself to human rights across the world and returned to writing plays. He also fulfilled a dream from his youth by directing the film version of his last play, Leaving. He also founded the Václav Havel Library for the public and researchers, which collects materials related to his work and political activities.

Former President Václav Havel died on 18th December 2011 at Hrádeček. In the last year of his life, he retired to seclusion. His last public appearance was a week before his death when he met with the Dalai Lama in Prague.

His health had been undermined by imprisonment and smoking. In 1996, doctors removed half of his lung because of a malignant tumour. Two years later, he underwent surgery in Innsbruck for a perforated colon.

Václav Havel was married twice. He married his first wife Olga (née Šplíchalová) in 1964 after an eight-year relationship. He spoke of her as his indispensable support in life. Olga Havlová died in January 1996. A year later he married the actress Dagmar Veškrnová.

Václav Havel’s legacy

Despite difficult times, Havel’s character did not lose his sense of humour and humanity. His ability to find humour in the absurdity of a situation was a key element of his resilience and an inspiration to many.

* The Warsaw Pact invasion was a military intervention carried out by the troops of the Soviet Union and other communist Warsaw Pact countries in August 1968. This action was directed against the reform movement in Czechoslovakia known as the ‘Prague Spring’.
